thread.title: There's something in the sewers: Mystery as tapping noise beneath street sparks probe by police and fire crew
thread.title_full: There's something in the sewers: Mystery as tapping noise beneath street sparks probe by police and fire crew

author: Caroline Jones
title: There's something in the sewers: Mystery as tapping noise beneath street sparks probe by police and fire crew
text:
Firefighters take a look inside the sewer (Photo: Derby Telegraph) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Police and fire crews had a mystery on their hands after strange sounds were heard in a sewer in a city centre. 
A member of the public reported hearing knocking and banging coming from one of the manholes in Tennant Street in Derby. 
A major rescue unit was called to the scene to pry open a manhole cover and take a look inside to find out whether a person or animal was trapped inside. 
But firefighters found nothing unusual and emergency services were no closer to finding out what was causing the unusual noises, the Derby Telegraph reported. Firefighters and police were called to the scene (Photo: Derby Telegraph) The noise has been heard at least twice in recent days (Photo: Derby Telegraph) 
The noises have been heard at least twice in recent days, said people at the scene. 
Police and a fire engine and major rescue unit from Derbyshire Fire and Rescue Service's Nottingham Road station were called at about 5.30pm on Wednesday evening. Read More Mysterious labyrinth of ISIS 'rat' tunnels dug beneath Mosul shrine reveal lost palace built six centuries before Jesus 
Fire service station manager Ben Smart, who is based at Ripley fire station, said a member of the public had contacted police after hearing knocking and banging coming from one of the manholes. 
He said officers contacted the fire service, who turned out with the rescue crew which has specialised equipment. Nothing unusual was found (Photo: Derby Telegraph) 
Mr Smart said: "We lifted the manhole but there is no way anyone could be down there. 
"It is the sewer." 
At the scene a teenage skateboarder, who did not want to be named, said that a few days ago someone else said they had heard knocking coming from underground in the same area. Like us on Facebook
